Improve GUI by rendering left and right panel with titles
commitResults.messageBody:
Include stub class as dependency injection for Book so that CI/CD
pass. Labels and titles for left and right panel to follow our
Figma mockup.

Use of gridpane with row and column coordinates so that it is easy
to create and maintain the GUI main window. For example, assigning
coordinates (0,0) and (0,1) left and right panel titles while
controlling the row constraints will give us amber space for our
patron and book list panels to be rendered properly.

commitResults.messageBody:
Text in person and book cards will be truncated if too long, thus
wrapText is set to true to allow to prevent text truncation.

Certain parameters of the book command are optional such as the
author and the category tags. Therefore, there is a need to check
and ensure that the GUI renders these fields properly. In the
BookList.fxml, the visibility and managed attributes of the label
are set to false be default and only toggled to true in BookCard
if the author list supplied is not empty.

Different book tags have different colors and will change as accord
based on the status of the book.

Package book: Add Book class and classes representing fields of Book
commitResults.messageBody:
There is lack of objects and utility classes representing books in a
library.

Our application requires such representations to be able to
keep track and store information of books.

Let's introduce the following classes in a separate book package to help
store information regarding books:
* Book - Representing a book with name, isbn, authors and category tags
* Author - Representing an author of a book
* ISBN - Representing the isbn of a book
* BookName - Representing the name of a book
* Add separate test classes to unit test each of the classes above

Each field is represented as a class so that we abide to the Open-Closed
Principle in SOLID. For example, Author may only contain a String now,
but we may extend Author to include other attributes of the author in
future.

All these information is encapsulated in a separate book package so as
to abide to the encapsulation principle of OOP.

commitResults.messageTitle: Book: Add sample data and utilities for testing
commitResults.messageBody:
There is no sample test data and sample books. This makes testing very
hard and inefficient.

Let's,
* Add a builder class for Book to instantiate Book test data
* Add sample book data in TypicalBooks
* Add utility functions to obtain sample book data in SampleDataUtil
* Add sample valid fields/attributes of books in CommandTestUtil

Using the Builder Pattern for instantiating test data is convenient and
flexible as it allows us to construct Book objects attribute by
attribute, which allows us to edit only certain fields during testing.

Refer to the book by Gang Of Four for more details on Builder Pattern.

commitResults.messageTitle: Book package : Adapt Storage and Model
commitResults.messageBody:
The small classes under Book package has already been adapted, but the
higher level classes concerning the overall Model and Storage is not
adapted to store Book object.

Let's,
* Create JsonAdaptedXYZ classes for XYZ = Book and Author to convert
Book and Author to Json objects
* Adapt Model and ModelManager so that we can perform CRUD operations
on a list of books in the model.
* Adapt AddressBook and ReadOnlyAddressBook to include Book
functionalities
* Adapt JsonSerializableAddressBook so that AddressBook can store
serialized JsonAdaptedBook data

Some unrelated test classes such as AddCommandTest are also modified
because they contain Stubs of interfaces modified above, and therefore
needs to implement the modifications in the stub.

commitResults.messageTitle: Storage and Model Component: Minor Refactoring and Adding Tests
commitResults.messageBody:
getTypicalAddressBook() is a method that is used for many test cases,
and is located inside TypicalPersons file.

It does not make sense to be inside that file because
getTypicalAddressBook() also needs to initialize the books, which are
inside TypicalBooks file.

Furthermore, the higher level Storage and Model components are yet to be
tested properly after the Book adaptation. Some test data json files are
also outdated.

Let's,
* Refactor getTypicalAddressBook() into a new TypicalAddressBook file,
and update all references to the method call in all test classes
* Update the test json data to include books
* Complete test classes for all Storage and Model components to provide
better test coverage

Updating test json data will prevent us the Storage component when
throwing error during testing. This is because the storage component
throws error when it tries to read book data from our sample data, but
the sample data does not contain "books" field.

commitResults.messageTitle: Fix checkstyle errors and change test data in TypicalPersonsAddressBook so that it is consistent with TypicalAddressBook to avoid failing test cases
Command: Made first step to refactor into packages
commitResults.messageBody:
Our current parser does not support the parsing of commands with
2-word command words such as "patron add" or "book edit"

Let's:
* Add a layer of abstraction (i.e. BookCommandParser and
PatronCommandParser) so that parseCommand() from the original top-level
parser can call the parser() functions in these newly created classes
* Package all patron related commands into patron package, and book
related edit, delete, find, list, add commands into book package
* Package the same way for patron command parsers and book command
parsers
* Remove "COMMAND_WORD" from individual command classes, and refactor
them as a public static variable in Command class

Refactoring "COMMAND_WORD" is needed as some of the command words are
the same for different groups of commands (e.g. patron and book commands
). Refactoring eases the import, and reduces the chances of having
inconsistencies. It is also easier to change in the future, if needed.

The layer of abstraction and packaging is also needed so that we apply
SLAP principals, and avoid having long method for parseCommand()
function.
